captions.text:
Good morning John; I love Tumblr text posts.
As they rise to the top of the most massive

slush pile in the history of the universe
getting six or even seven figures of notes.

Accumulating the endorsement of seemingly
everyone, they become almost objectively great.

Like no one could argue with their greatness.
And when I read them, I usually agree. A nugget

of insight, a fascinating explanation, a truly
daring set of puns.

Most text posts that break out into virality
are the height of a form -- a pretty weird

form, agreed, but I also like the Tumblr text
post because, like all media, they say a lot

about the culture that creates and honors
and promotes them. And here's one that I came

across quite a while ago that kinda stuck
with me, “What I’m really terrified of

is leading an average, ordinary life with
a regular job and an invariable routine, planned

holidays, an average household, fixed responsibilities
and not doing anything different to be remembered
by.”

This post has around half a million notes,
and that makes me a little worried because

John, as you have, for some reason, repeatedly
driven home over and over again, probably

because you struggle with this quite a lot
yourself, oblivion is inevitable and someday

there will be no one left to remember anything,
let alone you or me. Being remembered forever

is not a good goal because it is not an achievable
goal. But if that argument doesn’t work

for you, take a look at me. I am what people
call successful; I've had more than my share

of interesting life experiences. I've toured
in a rock band, been written about in the

New Yorker, helped raise over 2 million dollars
for charity, Crash Course is watched in thousands

of schools, and I don’t know if you heard
about this, but recently I interviewed the
President.

So you might ask, when was it for me when
I knew that I had made it? When was the moment

when I had the success statue and I got to
put it on this shelf right here next to Obi-Wan?

Was it when I was first recognized in public
or when we got one hundred thousand subscribers

or a million subscribers or when I was first
paying my bills with YouTube? Which day was

it when I became perpetually satisfied and
always happy? Yeah, it was none of the days.

Here’s the thing about success, if you're
smart enough and you're dedicated enough and

lucky enough and sacrifice enough, you too
will get to find out that none of it exists.

It’s made up. It’s just it’s not a real
thing.

You get successes, but you don’t get success.
The whole of everything of it does not lie

on that arbitrary yet remarkable thing that
you did that everyone says, “Yes, that.

That counts.” I've had those things, and
they do not bring long term satisfaction.

The satisfaction? The joy? That comes from
solving problems and making things. And often

times the recognition isn’t even a necessary
part of the process. So if I have any advice

for the five-hundred-thousand people who either
liked or reblogged that text post on Tumblr,

here it is: instead of thinking about what
you will and won’t accomplish in your life,

think about the problems that you have helped
solve and you will help solve and the things

that you're gonna help make and that you've
already helped make.

I don’t think I am alone in feeling like
the things that we help make and the problems

we help solve, those are the things that really
matter the things that actually affect the

world and that actually make us happy. And
maybe every person is unremarkable in that

we all make things every day. We make happiness
and we make families and we make sandwiches

and most fantastically of all we make ourselves.
John, I’ll see you on Tuesday.

End screen. And you know why we love video
games so much? Because they give us clear

defined problems to solve and value-laden
achievements to unlock, and I love it, which

is why Games with Hank officially today is
back with new series “Hank Green Plays The
Sims.”

And then of course you can adjust booby size
to the beat of the music.

Meet Jimmy Carter, he is like ninety years
old, so let's go ahead and make him an old

man. Oh good. Sul sul Jimmy Carter. I mean
I guess we could give him emo hair. Hahaha.

Oh no, no, what have I done! Ohhhhh God! You
look great. You're in great shape, Jimmy.

Leader of the free world? That’s not a lifetime
wish, Jimmy Carter. You already got to do
that.

title: You Will Be Forgotten ...And That's OK

comments.author: Abhishu Brahmecha

comments.text:
This is a thought that has ruptured my mind and now it is bleeding 
profusely with no signs of coagulation. I think the thing that has 
terrified me the most is that I will die without really having enjoyed 
anything. That because of this unending need to do something meaningful, I 
suppose in a grand scale, that it stops me from creating anything. I want 
desperately to be free of that burden and to enjoy the things I enjoy as 
they are. To not worry about the outcome. This idea has taken me to 
terrible places. I don't know exactly where this was going. But if anyone 
has any ideas how to let go of this mindset, please share. ﻿
comments.author: Preston Zubal

comments.text:
Through a series of unfortunate, then fortunate, then unfortunate again, 
then fortunate again events, I've been out of the Nerdfighter/YouTube 
community for almost six months. I started to get really depressed even 
though things are going "well" on paper because I felt I'd fallen so far 
behind on my dreams that I'd never be able to catch up.

After spending two days crying and being afraid that my depression is 
coming back, I suddenly remembered Hank and John and how happy they always 
made me feel, and how they somehow have the talent to make me comfortable 
in my discomfort, so I decided to start watching the videos I'd missed.

I came across this one and began to cry, because as always, Hank is 
perfectly right and knew just what to say. Oblivion is inevitable, but I 
made things in my tiny infinity that I thought were awesome.﻿

comments.text:
I haven't read any of the other comments here so I don't know if this has 
already been said. But in my opinion, most of the people in the world fear 
the exact opposite in the sense that their goal is stability when it comes 
to family and job...the safety of routine and being cared for by loved 
ones. so to me this just seems like a privileged firsty first worlder 
problem...which I do suffer from immensely. So instead of 'doing something 
great' I try to cultivate caring connective relationships. Which is hard 
since I have been raised in a culture that says "accomplish accomplish 
accomplish! Success is power and money and influence."
le sigh.﻿
comments.author: eli different

comments.text:
Oh hey, this was posted on my birthday :)

I'm very glad you made this video because that text post concerns me, too. 
It also sort of confuses me because the life they described... sounds... 
awesome? It sounds like a life filled with everyday adventures like going 
to school and falling in love and maybe having kids someday or planting a 
garden or rescuing wildlife, and just... being part of the world in a way 
that matters, despite how small and forgettable it may seem. Like, 
seriously, if I get to live a life like that, it'll be more than I ever 
expected.

Then I remember what it's like to be sixteen, like a lot of the people 
reblogging that probably are. Or younger, maybe. And I realize that's just 
where they are in life. I think they'll be okay someday. It just takes a 
bit of living to figure this stuff out sometimes.﻿

comments.text:
You will be forgotten and that's ok.

As a race humans are the sum of their parts, finite beings interacting, 
creating and solving the issues of the day. But while we are finite, the 
world will go on long after us when we have become the dust of the earth, 
reused and recycled to form new life and organisms. It should be that way. 
While Humans can do remarkable things, rugged individualism is of less 
intrinsic value than the value of what we can and do achieve and create as 
a collective.﻿

comments.text:
I always love the quote from The Man in the High Castle by Philip K Dick " 
Be small and you shall escape the jealousy of the great".

I realise there's a temptation to strive for fame but it comes at a great 
deal of personal cost and the idea of being remembered forever has a finite 
appeal, since no matter how long humanity continues for it will never be 
eternal. All things are finite and that is what makes them beautiful, this 
time we have, these things we see can only be experienced here and now. I 
realise its much easier to live in the past or the future, I do it too 
often myself but taking moments to appreciate the present help put things 
in perspective a great deal.﻿

comments.author: LordDoppelgamer

comments.text:
Normally I'm not too bothered by the fact that my life didn't go as 
planned. I take issue when people point out that I'm currently 
accomplishing less in my life than I did when I was younger and had less 
opportunity to do so. My response is anger and excuses. Deep down I fear 
that that's all I am, and any attempt to change it is due to one of those 2 
things. I'm concerned lately that I don't actually have a sense of self, 
and that I just am the way I am because others think that's how I am.
The gnawing fear that all my passions and hobbies, hopes and dreams, are 
all the construct of someone else and that if I removed all that I'd be 
completely empty.
And there's no way for me to determine the reality because I and anyone 
else who can vouch for my existence is viewed from my point of view and 
I'll just hear what I want to to make myself feel better.
As a result I've determined that, if cloning ever becomes a thing I want to 
fight my clone to the death to prove to myself that I'm me.﻿
comments.author: Hoshimaru57

comments.text:
Jee man, I work week days, have weekends off, as an aviation maintenance 
technician, I make good money, Im looking at buying my first small house, 
i'm looking forward to the huge increase in wage when I get my M2, i'm 
looking forward to owning my Dodge Challenger, I go out on the weekends if 
not working overtime.

Am I happy? Well, yea. I have a career, I have money, I have a good future 
ahead of me, vacations, traveling, nice car to ride around in during sunset.

Of course, like anyone, i'd love to have an infinite amount of money so I 
can live in mansions across the globe and do nothing but relax for the rest 
of my life.

But i'm happy with what i've got and what i'll have, it sounds mundane 
saying "Work 7-330, weekdays, for life, own a home, work, etc"

But if we point out the mundane tasks than life seems boring, what about 
the enjoyable moments inbetween? The dinners out, the vacations, the random 
crazy things that happen at home or at work, the family outings, that girl 
last week, that hiking trip you took, that camping trip that went bad, that 
bear that chased ya down, that car that almost hit ya..

Shit life is loaded with events that make it interesting. ﻿

comments.author: sujana bora

comments.text:
It was a really hot, muggy day in the middle of a horrible summer and I 
felt like death. I was 17 and had suddenly become an adult after my mom got 
sick. I had to walk to the store to do our shopping and then carry 
everything home. On that day my haul was too heavy. I was sweaty and 
exhausted and the cars at the crosswalk refused to stop. Then, a women who 
I had passed in the parking lot 10 min. earlier pulled out into the 
intersection and used her car to block the entire road just so I could 
finally get across. She asked if I was okay and if I needed help. She was 
the first person in a long time to ask if I was okay. It felt so good to be 
acknowledged. I declined her offer because my house was close, but she gave 
me hope. Although it was not something I would call a "success" or an 
"accomplishment" I will always remember her because I felt like shit that 
day and she took the time to help me.

I guess this is my long winded way of saying that if you are kind to 
others, even in the smallest ways, you will be remembered at least for a 
little while. This really is something that happens in the real world and 
it's not just a story people tell so you'll be nice to others. You can have 
an impact on other people's lives and you will be remembered for it in 
small, personal ways.﻿
comments.author: Jessica-Robyn W.

comments.text:
Posting because I've been reading more Brené Brown lately and your video 
ties in nicely with this quote of hers:

"When I look at narcissism through the vulnerability lens, I see the 
shame-based fear of being ordinary. I see the fear of never feeling 
extraordinary enough to be noticed, to be lovable, to belong, or to 
cultivate a sense of purpose."

And from one of her other books:

"We seem to measure the value of people's contributions (and sometimes 
their entire lives) by their level of public recognition. In other words, 
worth is measured by fame and fortune. Our culture is quick to dismiss 
quiet, ordinary, hardworking men and women. In many instances, we equate 
*ordinary* with *boring* or, even more dangerous, *ordinary* has become 
synonymous with *meaningless*."

I highly recommend her books to anyone who's had these struggles.﻿

horrible. One person's vision of mediocrity is another person's vision of 
success, I guess.﻿

comments.author: taylor obermüller

comments.text:
I wish to be remembered. Not as a dumb pop star or as a serial killer or a 
dictator of some remote island, but as someone who inspired others, gave 
them hope, and showed them how joyful, happy, and meaningful life can be. I 
want to make an impact on the world around me. I want to travel, to 
explore, to express myself, and teach others how to do the same. I want to 
show others that it's never to early or too late to make your dreams come 
true and that all it takes is passion, dedication, and hard work. I want to 
do so many things in my life. I have at least 7 different careers that I 
WILL peruse and succeed in. You know how I know that? Because I believe in 
myself. There are so many people in this world who will put you down, tell 
you it's impossible, too hard, and that life is too short to be more that 
one thing. I want to be the person who showed everyone that you CAN do 
anything and everything you put your heart to. I want to be that person who 
turned all her dreams into reality and showed others they could do the 
same. I want to be great, so I will. I will be great and I will inspire 
others and I will be remembered. It might be by a small group of people, it 
might be by billions. Regardless of the number, I know that I will make my 
life count.﻿
comments.author: taylor obermüller

comments.author: taylor obermüller

comments.text:
I think the Tumblr text post was less about being remembered forever and 
ever and more about finding and doing what you love and being good and 
successful at it. It's not, about fame and remembrance, it's about boredom 
and mediocrity. It's about waking up one day when you're 45 and realizing 
you sacrificed or failed at achieving your dreams and you're stuck in this 
boring and soul crushing occupation that you have no escape from because 
you are unintelligent, not creative, and just plain average. That is what 
is terrifying. ﻿

The idea that I wouldn't be remembered used to scare me too, but the thing 
is - you will never ever know the effect you've had on the world. You might 
not be remembered perse, but that doesn't mean your time on earth is 
irrelevant. You affect the people around you constantly. You change people 
in tiny ways all the time. You are constantly affecting the course of 
history. Even if you won't be remembered for it, what you do counts for 
something.﻿

comments.text:
I actually have no idea what to think of this LOL 

Alexander Graham Bell will always be remembered, Thomas Edison and creators 
of the beginnings of things that they're gonna use in the future are going 
to be remembered - so if you really want to not be forgotten then you'll 
have to work (obviously) really hard. Many inventions are mistakes, but 
it's so easy for people to forget how to be 'creative' or 'innovative' as 
each day passes and I always see people post (especially from Tumblr) how 
they don't want to be forgotten, yet they don't do anything to make 
themselves seen. I only really have a problem with people that wish for 
something but don't work for it - a wish is useless unless you do something 
about it. ﻿

comments.author: Meg Hannon

comments.text: Hanks videos are so great... this is really something to think about﻿
comments.author: I know write

comments.text:
To add on to the sentiments expressed before me, I just have this to add. 
You know, i love this channel especially because of the comment sections 
(of course its content too). They are almost overwhelmingly positive. And 
if anything, the majority of disagreements are replied to in an adult 
manner. For something as mundane as a positive comment on a youtube video, 
it seems like such a hard thing to come by. Thank you for being awesome 
nerdfighters<3﻿
comments.author: ohdarah
